title: fidelma-cook-one-politician-face-modern-confident-scotland
story: If anything, since then that almost-yearning has increased and more and more on social media one sees praise and plaudits from English voters who wish Nicola Sturgeon could be the UKrsquos next leader.It reached a peak after the recent Leadersrsquo Debate which saw Johnson and Swinson go down like nine pins in a bowling alley ndash one openly ridiculed the other, seemingly ill-prepared and dogged by a dismal, uncharitable voting past. Oh, and a dodgy accent.Corbyn tottered at times but remained upright. Next to Johnson he almost, almost, came across as a steady hand on the tiller. That is how far wersquove come in this shambles.Sturgeon never flinched, and only the most rabid anti-SNP fanatic could carve failure from what was a triumphant appearance by any standards.For almost single-handedly, and this is not by any means a denigration of any other of the SNPrsquos politicians, she has become the sane voice in a dystopian political landscape where an increasingly autocratic Johnson vows to curb democracy itself to his whims.She is the face, not just of independence, but of a Scotland confident in its right to stand alongside other nations in a united Europe.Interviewed by Andrew Neil, it was said afterwards that she had lost some of her clout by seeming discomforted and unable to answer his questionson currency, fiscal timescales and SNHS problems.The woman who never was, Ruth Davidson, was one of the first to tweet her glee calling it a lsquodoing.rsquo It was a bitter whoop from a sad failure who never once put herself up for a similar interrogation.Me ndash I saw a woman far from rattled or being given a lsquodoing,rsquo simply exasperated that Neil didnrsquot go off his y cue sheet to engage in her answers. I saw a woman who was honest on the failures, cut short as she tried to explain the why and the how.Strange, I never thought I would write such words when I first saw Ms Sturgeon in action many, many years ago on my occasional forays into Scottish politics on behalf of the Mail on Sunday.I couldnrsquot understand who, what, this small woman always scurrying along in the wake of others, actually did. To me, to my shame in hindsight, she was always an acolyte, never a player.But when yoursquore too close to it all you can sometimes pay far too much attention to the tittle tattle, the clever bon mots and witticisms of those with their own mill to grind. Usually politics-only reporters.Politics, as Irsquom sure you know, is a dirty, ugly game of egos and slights personal ambition rising often above the ideals such people came in to serve and destroying many of the best.It has taken distance the distance of another country to see as clearly as one can without the whispers ndash without the muddying of waters. No attendant white noise.And from that distance I have watched her grow in gravitas and continue, in leaps and bounds, the progression of a once-reviled oddball, of an occasionally suspect movement, into a serious political force.I am an outsider, an insider, Irish and English, and by virtue of your big hearts, Scottish by familiarity and adoption. I have earned my right to speak. So, have you.Today as I write, in her column in , Suzanne Moore said: "Sturgeon wants another independence referendum. Corbyn says she canrsquot have it ndash but she knows she could get him to change his mind. And she will outlast him, letrsquos be honest. She speaks more passionately against the Tories than he does."Sturgeon has what so many politicians lack. Hinterland. Johnsonrsquos is ndash well, Latin and more children than he can count. Corbynrsquos is jam today and tomorrow. Sturgeon reads, laughs, connects and does not suffer fools gladly.Maybe itrsquos time to move to Scotland while the rest of this country gets its house in order."Twenty years ago, , even , one would not have seen this said about a leader or Scotland. Itrsquos actually quite extraordinary.Finally, the country is being given respect, and from the number of times both Johnson and Corbyn are referencing the SNP, as the days shorten towards the ballot, theyrsquore worried, seriously worried.And they should be. You can only belittle so much in Parliament, in toss away references, in manesto ignorance before the worm turns.I respectfully suggest ndash from my distance ndash the worm has not only turned, itrsquos doing somersaults.

title: scotland-left-scraps-off-table-2bn-wind-farm-boom
story: Unions are furious at what they see as ldquothe scraps off the table that Scotland has received in the work on the pound billion Neart Na Gaoithewind farm off the Fe coast, awarded by EDF, the French state energy giant.Camleys Cartoon: Green energy jobs.The Herald can also reveal that Scotland has lost further important project work, worth hundreds of millions of pounds to England, Germany, Finland and France.The poundm Saipem turbine jackets deal will mean Canadian-owned Burntisland Fabricationsyards in Arnish and Fe continuing to lose out in the ldquogreen manufacturing revolution getting an estimated % of this valuable and crucial manufacturing work. Saipem will also supply and install an additional two jackets for offshore substations.But while the fanfare over the finances for what is one of Scotlandrsquos biggest renewable energy projects was made yesterday, a Saipem source stated that the Scottish contract, which it was hoped would revive BiFabrsquos fortunes in Scotland, is yet be signed.BiFab, which employs around , workers was rescued from the brink of administration by the Scottish Government with a loan valued at pound.m, but then was purchased by Canadian firm DF Barnes, although hundreds of jobs were shed.The workforce is now estimated to then stand at just The only new confirmed jobs Scotland would gain is  over  years, at a new maintenance base at Eyemouth harbour.It has added further fuel to the anger over what unions have described as a renewables market ldquochaos which is increasingly placing Scotlandrsquos green energy revolution in foreign hands. EDF Renewables UK chief executive Matthieu Hue said that they would continue to work ldquovery hard to maximise the potential of the project for the local supply chain in Scotland.But he angered union leaders when he added: ldquoWe do not ignore the supply chain outside Scotland - in fact Scotland doesnrsquot have all the skills and contractors yet to be able to bid in all aspects of wind farm construction.He added:But as the growth of offshore wind continues, we certainlyhope and push for Scottish companies to increase their input into offshore projects. Of the BiFab yard he said:ldquoIt has been mothballed for some time and itrsquos important the yard is able to build up the capacity and we certainly think it will allow BiFab and its owner to do that.Peter Welsh, head of campaigns with GMB Scotland: ldquoOver  years ago we had the then Scotlandrsquos first minister Alex Salmond talk about the country becoming the Saudi Arabia of renewables. Now we are fighting for what are scraps from our own offshore wind sector.ldquoIf we are only getting % of a manufacturing contract, with the remaining % being done halfway around the world, that is not success, that is failure.The Herald can reveal that in a separate contract worth nearly poundm, the Milan-headquartered telecom and electricity cable group Prysmian will produce and supply submarine cables at its centre of excellence in Pikkala, Finland. Further land cables will be manufactured in Gron, France.Further parts for the turbines are being produced in Hull, and Cuxhaven, Germany.The wind farm project is due to be completed in  and will provide power for , homes, with offshore construction to start in June .A Scottish Government spokesman said: ldquoThe terms and conditions of the jacket construction contract are still being agreed between Saipem and BiFab.ldquoThe commencement of work on the Neart na Gaoithe wind farm is positive news for the Port of Dundee, Eyemouth Harbour, and BiFab in Fe, which are set to benefit from the associated jobs and investment in the community, demonstrating the strengths and potential of our indigenous supply chain.ldquoThe Government is actively encouraging developers to explore every possible option to help the Scottish supply chain in the development of future offshore wind projects.

title: debate-future-monarchy---nicola-sturgeon
story: Andrew stepped down from public dutiesafter mounting pressure following his BBC Newsnight interview about his friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.After the programme aired, the duke faced criticism for showing a lack of empathy towards the victims of his late friend,who took his own le in prison earlier this year while awaiting trial on sex trafficking and conspiracy charges.:Letters: Monarchy will not be relevant to daily le in an independent ScotlandIn an interview on ITV News At Ten on Thursday, Ms Sturgeon said a debate about the monarchy should not be a distraction from Epsteinrsquos victims.However, when askedthe issue made her consider whether the monarchy is fit for purpose, she replied: ldquoI think it raises a number of questions.ldquoI think there is a debate to be had about the longer term future of the monarchy, one of the things though in the context of Prince Andrew that I feel very strongly about is that a debate about the monarchy shouldnrsquot be a distraction from Epsteinrsquos victims and how they now get whatever justice they can get and get the truth and the ability to move on.:Opinion Matrix: Politics and the monarchyldquoAnd I think while, yes, there is a debate to be had about the former, I donrsquot think it should become conflated with that or be used in any way to sort of take attention from that.The duke has resigned from a large number of patronages, and seen organisations he was once involved with sever ties in the wake of the Newsnight interview.

title: michael-gove-turned-away-channel-4-climate-debate
story: The Conservatives have made a formal complaint to Ofcoms election committee as an ice sculpture was used in Mr Johnsons place for the debate, which was broadcast last night.The broadcaster said the invitation was for leaders only and put an ice sculpture in place of Boris Johnson.Former Environment Secretary Michael Gove attempted to enter the debate saying he hadin place of Mr Johnson.:Conservative source in threat to Channel  over ice stuntAfter being refused entry, the Tories accused the broadcaster of "conspiring" with Jeremy Corbyn to block them from the debate.They have written to Ofcoms election committee, saying that the use of an ice sculpture in place of the prime minister was a "provocative partisan stunt".Mr Gove also posted footage of himself arriving and askinghe could be the Conservative voice in the debate. Upon arrival, he was told lsquowe werenrsquot expecting yoursquo.Before the debate, the editor of Channel  News, Ben de Pear, tweeted a picture of Mr Gove and the Prime Ministerrsquos father Stanley Johnson, who were both at the studio.Mr Gove also posted footage of himself arriving and askinghe could be the Conservative voice in the debate.After the programme, Mr de Pear said: ldquoIt was very kind of Michael Gove to offer himself to appear on Channel  News this evening, and we always welcome him on the programme.ldquoHowever, as we made clear to him repeatedly, because he is not the leader of the Conservative Party, his participation was not required at tonightrsquos #climatedebate ndash which was strictly for party leaders only.Rebecca Newsom, head of politics at Greenpeace UK, said: ldquoGiven how poorly Boris Johnsonrsquos manesto scored in our climate and nature ranking, itrsquos no surprise he refused to take part.ldquoThis could have been an opportunity for him to set the record straight and commit to stronger policies.:Publics overriding emotion is "frustration" in first TV election debate, says pollldquoBut running scared doesnrsquot just spark witty hashtags highlighting his cowardice, it demonstrates to voters a serious lack of leadership over a crisis that affects us all.Mr Johnson has also yet to agree to a slot for a head-to-head interview with Mr Neil on the BBC who has so far interviewed SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.Tonight I went to Channel  to talk about climate change but Jeremy Corbyn and Nicola Sturgeon refused to debate a Conservative #climatedebate pic NYdQOzCgNHe was invited to the spin room and told he would have time allocated but Mr Gove said that while he appreciated the offer "what Id really like to dothats OK is to just take part in the debate itself. Because all the other parties will be represented and I just think its only fairwe have a Conservative voice there as well.When askedBoris Johnson would be attending, Mr Gove said: "He cant at the moment, so having been Environmental Minister and as the Minister whos responsible for the Climate Change Summit in Glasgow next year, I thought it would be fair just to give me a chance to have a debate.

title: rennie-says-not-accept-indyref2-price-stopping-brexit
story: The Scottish Liberal Democrat leader said he would not want a second independence vote to add to the existing ldquoconstitutional chaos.He said he was making it ldquocrystal clear to electors that he would not vote for Indyref ldquowhatever the circumstances.He said: "Wherever we are, whatever opportunity we get, we will vote against another independence referendum because we want to learn the lessons [of ], not repeat them.Launching his partyrsquos manesto at Murrayfield Curling Rink in Edinburgh, Mr Rennie said he wanted to stop both Brexit and independence, and ldquobuild a brighter future without them.He described the two constitutional issues as ldquothese terrible twins of ision, of cost, of borders, of lost opportunities .He said: ldquoLiberal Democrats will stop another independence referendum in Scotland, and stop the ision and chaos independence would cause.ldquoWe need to learn the lessons of Brexit, not repeat the mistakes with independence.ldquoCutting ties with our closest neighbours is a backwards and isolating move ndash thatrsquos been the lesson of the past three years.ldquoIndependence would bring all the chaos and distraction of Brexit, but multiply it.ldquoOur ties with Europe are deep and valuable. Our ties with the UK are even deeper and even more valuable. Cutting ties with Europe after  years is torture.ldquoImagine the pain of breaking -year-old ties. Just like Brexit, it would be the vulnerable who would suffer the most.ldquoThe last thing we need is another bitter and isive independence referendum.The -page manesto includes pledges to end fuel poverty in Scotland by , ensure mental health is tackled with the same urgency as physical health and  hours a week of free care from all children between nine months and starting school.However these are devolved areas, and so would also need LibDems in power at Holyrood.The manesto also proposes an extra pound.bn for the Scottish budget to use for public services, and a poundbn long term fund for infrastructure investment.Boasting a "radical, credible and detailed plan" to tackle climate change, the party also said it wanted to reverse Tory cuts to Universal Credit and create a fairer corporate tax system.Writing in the foreword, UK LibDem leader Jo Swinson said: ldquoVoters are being told that the only choice is between the Conservatives and Labour. But when I look at Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn, I know that I could do a better job as Prime Minister than either of them.ldquoOur country deserves better that what is on offer from two tired old parties, each led by men who want to reuse ideas from the past - whether the s or s - and gamble with our childrenrsquos futures.With Nicola Sturgeon willing to work in a ldquoprogressive alliance to keep Boris Johnson out of power and secure a Peoplersquos Vote, Mr Rennie was asked whether he would accept Indyref as the price for stopping Brexit alongside Labour and the SNP in such a scenario.He said: ldquoNo, because wersquore not wanting to add to the chaos. We want to make it stop. We want to end the constitutional chaos, and we will use our votes in parliament at every opportunity to make it stop.ldquoWersquore not interested in putting Boris Johnson or Jeremy Corbyn into power. Wersquove made that clear. We will vote at every opportunity in parliament to make it stop and nothing will stop us doing that.ldquoItrsquos up to the other parties to explain whether theyrsquore going to do coalitions together but donrsquot count on us.The manesto says the election of a LibDem majority government at Westminster on a clear stop Brexit  would be a democratic mandate to revoke Article  to stop Brexit.Asked about the election of an SNP majority government at Holyrood on a clear Indyref  similarly being a democratic mandate for a new vote, he said: ldquoYoursquore dealing with hypotheticals on hypotheticals.When it was put to him the question was not far-fetched, but about a potential repeat of the Holyrood result of , which led to the LibDems accepting an independence referendum, he said: ldquoWhat wersquore saying is,people vote for us, this is how wersquoll cast our votes in the parliament. Wherever we are, whatever opportunity we get, we will vote against another independence referendum because we want to learn the lessons, not repeat them.Pressed on the LibDems accepting a referendum in  after an SNP majority win, he said his partyrsquos position now was to oppose Indyref regardless of the election result.He said: ldquoWe didnrsquot say this before . We are saying very clearly - vote for us, we will vote against it at every opportunity. You canrsquot go into an election saying wersquore going to do one thing, butsomebody  gets a certain number of seats wersquore going to do something dferent. Thatrsquos not democracy. Itrsquos democratic thatyou vote for us, this is what you get.Eventhe SNP won another majority in , you would not accept a majority vote in the parliament  ldquoWe donrsquot, because wersquore against it.Wersquore against it. I know itrsquos hard for people to accept that we will just follow through on what wersquore saying wersquore going to do, but wersquore up front about it. I think the voter I spoke to last night, who I was giving an assurance that whatever the circumstances were, I would against another independence referendum, I think she might be rather upsetI did something dferent in the parliament.ldquoItrsquos pretty straightforward. Irsquom saying to people on the doorsteps. Irsquom saying to people on the leaflets, Irsquom saying to people in the manesto, thatrsquos what yoursquoll getyou vote for us.With Ms Swinson under fire for her record in the Tory-LibDem Coalition of -, he said the party was "rebuilding" its relationship with voters.He said: "Wersquore growing. The indications are wersquove almost doubled out support just within a few years. In  we had a dficult result. In  we bounced straight back. We won seats back from the SNP that wersquod lost. In  we quadrupled the number of seats we had. And wersquore set to grow again this time round.ldquoI think we are rebuilding with the voters that relationship because people see we are very clear with things, and we will do what we say. I think the party will go on to further success."He cited his partys early position on stopping Brexit as an example.ldquoWe were alone [after the  vore]. People saw we were sticking to our principles and saying what we believed. Over the last three and a half years wersquove built that support. Thatrsquos why people have come with us. We stuck through thick and then even when it was unpopular. Thatrsquos why people are rebuilding that relationship with us, and why wersquore growing in the polls as well.Asked about Ms Swinson being Prime Minister on December , he said he was ldquonot a psephologist and the voters would decide.He said: "Irsquom optimistic about our opportunity to grow in this election campaign, but itrsquos up to the voters to decide by how much. I have confidence in Jo. I think shersquos a great leader, and I think shersquoll do well in this campaign."Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: "This Liberal Democrat manesto reflects the fact Jo Swinson has more experience serving in a Tory government than Boris Johnson."It is nothing more than a re-hash of the same old ideas implemented by Nick Clegg and Jo Swinson in their time in government with the Conservatives.ldquoFour years on, the Lib Dems have still not come to terms with their role in imposing austerity on this country and have only empty rhetoric and the continuation of universal credit to offer the people of Scotland.ldquoThose who have suffered and are still suffering from the cuts imposed by the Tory-Lib Dem government wonrsquot be fooled.ldquoThe people of Scotland neither want nor need the Tory-lite Lib Dems. Only Labour can and will deliver the real change Scotland needs, with an additional pound billion of investment in Scotlandrsquos economy, public services people and communities.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: THE launch of the Scottish Tory manesto got off to a dire start as candidate Moira Benny forgot the name of her target seat in her introduction. ldquoIrsquom the candidate for Dunfermline and North Fe, eh+, West Fe! she blundered. Boss Jackson Carlaw saved the day by joking about Nicola Sturgeonrsquos TV grilling the previous night. ldquoIrsquom sorry to have to tell you wersquore cancelling this launch in favour of a re-run of the Andrew Neil interview.DumberbartonshireMS BENNYrsquoS map blindness seemed to be catching. Just a few hours later, the SNPrsquos John Nicolson informed a hustings in Ochil  South Perthshire that only he could beat the Tories ldquohere in East Dunbartonshire. His gaffe led to plenty of jokes at the SNP manesto launch in Glasgow the next morning. When hacks noted Mr Nicolsonrsquos absence, it was suggested hersquod gone to Orkney  Shetland by mistake.How long you got THAT wasnrsquot the biggest laugh of the launch, which was held in a massive warehouse in Yorkhill. That came when a TV reporter asked Nicola Sturgeon to spell out why she thought Boris Johnson was ldquounfit for office. The FM smiled. ldquoIrsquom happy to do that, she said.But Irsquom conscious we donrsquot have the let on this venue.Door belleSTEAMY news from the campaign in Edinburgh West. When LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton was out canvassing a door was opened by a woman naked but for a towel. ldquoOh, thank goodness yoursquore here, come in! she exclaimed. Alas, he had to disappoint her. He was not the plumber of her dreams.Two Fs in FeMEANWHILE, LibDem leader Willie Rennie got a rather cooler welcome in Leven. Opening her door, one voter recognised him and declared: ldquoF***! Oh f***! An election. Ugh, but Irsquoll vote for you. She then slammed the door in his face. ldquoI donrsquot mind mindpeople are rude, so long as they vote from me, he told Unspun. Soyou feel like giving a politician a therapeutic slagging, you know who to call.Labour painTOUGH times at Scottish Labourrsquos media operation where lots of press releases are being followed up by corrections. Like the one that forget to give the time for the partyrsquos manesto launch. New spindoctor Conrad Landin has been dubbed lsquoCrashrsquo Landin by the Holyrood press corps.

title: jeane-freeman-admits-mistakes-made-way-gp-contract-affected-rural-doctors
story: Ms Freeman told the annual conference of Scotlandrsquos GP leaders that they had her ldquounequivocal commitment that she would not reduce funds set aside to top up rural practice incomes, but vowed that the next phase of the new GP contract would do more to close the earnings gap between urban and rural practices.: GPs travelling from England to plug gaps in rural Highland and island practicesMs Freeman said: ldquoI accept that we could have done more earlier to recognise the problems in Phase  of the contract in terms of rural and remote general practice.ldquoSir Lewis Ritchie has led the Remote and Rural General Practice Working Group and I accept his recommendations in full, including those in relation to the Minimum Practice Income Guarantee. You have my unequivocal commitment to maintain that guarantee. ldquoThe introduction of the new Scottish GP contract was overwhelmingly rejected by GPs based in rural and island practices, but their votes were outweighed by the majority of GPs who are based in the Central Belt or cities.The controversy rested on the contractrsquos Scottish Workload Allocation Formulawhich determined how much taxpayer funding each practice was owed.The way the sums were calculated resulted in practices in more affluent urban areas with high elderly populations getting the highest uplts in funding. In comparison, many rural practices with lower patient lists and practices in more deprived areas - where residents are less likely to visit a GP - got little or no extra money.In some cases the formula indicated that their funding should be reduced, but in these cases the Scottish Government allocated special payments to ensure they did not end up worse of that before.: Rural GPs in Scotland vote to reject new contractHowever, GPs in rural practices argued that the potential to earn substantially more in urban practices would exacerbate existing staff shortages in rural Scotland, and that the formula failed to account for the extra services rural GPs provide in areas where there is no nearby hospital.Ms Freeman said Phase  of the contract would address discrepancies in GP pay. Practices have been asked todata to the Scottish Government and BMA for the first time detailing their income, expenses and workforce, including practice running costs and how much GPs take out as salary.Dr Andrew Buist, chair of BMA Scotlandrsquos GP committee, said the information would be used to address iations in GP earnings and bring them into line with salaries of hospital consultants, without undermining GPsrsquo independent contractor status.He said: ldquoThe earnings of all GPs in Scotland should be comparable to that of hospital consultants for core clinical work.ldquoAnd like consultants, GPs should also be able to earn additionally from enhanced services, private work and other sources of income.

title: energy-boss-accuses-parties-losing-focus-climate
story: ScottishPower chief executive Keith Anderson said Labour promises to take back control of the Britainrsquos energy network meant ldquolosing focus on the issue of tackling the climate emergency.Mr Anderson was responding to comments made by Glasgow North East Labour candidate Paul Sweeney as part of a climate hustings organised by the firm with WWF and The Herald.The event, hosted by journalist Bernard Ponsonby at ScottishPowerrsquos headquarters in Glasgow, featured representatives from the five main Scottish parties taking questions from an audience of around  people.Mr Sweeney said  under a Labour government would involve further state intervention planning in the economy, describing it as one in which ldquothe absurdity of having to search around for dferent gas and electricity bills would be over and the ldquogas board and electric board ed.He added: ldquoIt is one intergrated system, letrsquos extend public ownership and democratic ownership across our economy. But speaking after the event, Mr Anderson warned the debate meant parties were ldquolosing focus on the climate emergency.He said: ldquoWe think the target to get to  is incredibly challenging. We want to focus on that.ldquoLetrsquos focus on tackling climate change, letrsquos focus on the drive to get the electrication of transport and the heating system, thatrsquos a much better thing for us all to debate rather than focus on who owns what bits of asset in the ground.ldquoThat becomes a distraction, it slows us all down, it takes focus off the real issue, so we would far rather have a debate and a conversation about how we tackle climate change.He added: ldquoTo us, that is far more relevant and far more important than worrying and arguing about who is going to spend what buying what.Scottish Labourrsquos manesto calls for the creation of a new lsquoNational Energy Agencyrsquo to own and maintain the national grid infrastructure, with a Scotland-specic operator responsible for decarbonising electricity and heat.In a thorny debate, participants clashed on issues including agriculture, controversy surrounding onshore wind and the Scottish Governmentrsquos record on tree planting among a host of other topics.The event, which was streamed live on The Heraldrsquos Facebook page, aimed to explore where the parties stood on environmental issues ahead of the December  vote. Scottish Greens representative Mags Hall took aim at the hypocrisy of the SNP, represented by the partyrsquos Westminster spokesperson on transport, infrastructure and energy Alan Brown, over their abstention from voting on Heathrow expansion and their willingness to remain a part of Nato while calling for the removal of Trident nuclear submarine from Scottish waters.In a feisty exchange, Greens researcher Ms Hall criticised Mr Brown for the SNP stepping away from the vote on the expansion of the airport, yet allowing Heathrow bosses to sponsor a ldquofree bar at the partyrsquos Spring conference.Meanwhile, Scottish Conservative MSP Jamie Greene came under fire for asserting Brexit would not have an adverse impact on the climate emergency, while Liberal Democrat MSP Liam McArthur took aim at the ldquodangerous view that incremental changes could not help in the fight against climate change.

title: nicola-sturgeon-infuriates-brexit-party-chair-tv-debate
story: The First Minister got under Richard Ticersquos skin in a seven-way debate on the BBC.It followed Labourrsquos Rebecca Long-Bailey insisting that, despite his denials, Boris Johnson would put the NHS on the table in any post-Brexit trade deal with the US.Asked about a Labour email claiming that people might face a five figure bill for cancer treatment or pay to give birth, she said: ldquoCertainly,we privatise our NHS, that could be the direction of travel.: The BBC General Election debate as it happenedTory Rishi Sunak, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, said the privatisation claim was ldquototally and utterly ridiculous, while Mr Tice told her to ldquostop scaremongering."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Watch as Nicola Sturgeon clashes with Brexit Partys Richard Tice in BBC debate","description": "Watch as Nicola Sturgeon clashes with Brexit Partys Richard Tice in BBC debate","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media OLggX poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests OLggX.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": At the end of the -minute debate, Mr Tice reacted furiously when Sturgeon needled him further on the issue.In answer to a question about what he would say to Donald Trumpthey had  seconds with him on his UK visit next week, Mr Tice said: ldquoLetrsquos get a quick trade deal done.To audience laughter, Ms Sturgeon added: ldquolsquoAnd herersquos our NHS,rsquo is what he would say.Mr Tice fumed: ldquoOh nonsense! Stop this scaremongering. Itrsquos pathetic! Just lying to the British people continually.When Ms Sturgeon shot back ldquoOh I think yoursquove got form on that, Mr Tice was left staring at her open-mouthed in disdain.ldquoExtraordinary, he muttered.Plaid Cymru leader Adam Price got the biggest cheer from the audience by saying he would tell the US President: ldquoResign and take Boris with you.:Debate to be had about future of monarchy - Nicola SturgeonSNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said: ldquoTonight we saw another hugely impressive performance by Nicola Sturgeon ndash making the clear case that Scotlandrsquos future should be in Scotlandrsquos hands so that we can build a fairer, more prosperous country.ldquoShe completely exposed Boris Johnsonrsquos plans - with the Tory representative repeatedly refusing to rule out a No Deal Brexit, despite the absolutely catastrophic effects that would have on communities and businesses in Scotland, and across the UK.ldquoThere is no such thing as a good Brexit, with all forms of crashing out of the EU leaving us poorer and worse off.Tory party chair James Cleverly said: ldquoThis debate was a clear demonstration of the gridlock and delay the country would face under a Corbyn government propped up by Nicola Sturgeons SNP and the Liberal Democrats.ldquoWhether you voted leave or remain, itrsquos time to move forward. Under Corbyn, wersquod be stuck in neutral and nothing would change, with the British people subjected to higher taxes, fewer jobs, more debt and the chaos of two more referendums.

title: boorach-scots-words-need-get-next-weeks
story: Andyou want more, try this extract from the new book  Favourite Scots Words. For over a decade, The Herald has published the Scottish Language Dictionariesrsquo Scots Word of the Week and the new book gathers some of the best. The words demonstrate the breadth and ersity of the Scots language. And who knows, they must just get you through the election.BLELLUM noun an idle, ignorant, talkative manThat blellum is still used or known at all is largely due to Robert Burnsrsquo epic poem Tam orsquo Shanter penned in  where Tam is described as a lsquoblethering, blustering, drunken blellumrsquo. In so few words, we have a picture of a talkative, sometimes boastful, possibly diminutive, man.Its use in Scots is not confined to Burns. The Dictionary of the Scots Language reveals that the word also appears in John MacTaggartrsquos Gallovidian Encyclopedia of  where he defines it as lsquoan ignorant talkative fellow.rsquo From Lanark in , William Stewart in his Lilts and Larks frae Larkie describes a character in the terms: lsquoThus he raved, the senseless blellum.rsquo Although many recent usages do indeed refer to Tam, there are some instances which do not. Pete Fortune writing in the anthology A Tongue in Yer Heiddescribes a character thus: lsquoIn face auld Tosh helliprsquoThis seems to call into question the veracity of whatever Auld Tosh was about to say. Regarding the etymology, The Dictionary of the Scots Language suggests that it is perhaps a conflation of English lsquoblabbe, A gurgling noise with the lips in a liquid and skellum, A worthless fellow, scamp, scoundrel, rogue, now sometimes used playfully to a young boy. rsquoANNAKERrsquoS MIDDEN noun a mess, a shamblesThe Dictionary of the Scots Languagersquos earliest example of the above phrase used in this sense is from central Scotland in . This was firstly interpreted in the dictionary as lsquoa knackerrsquos midden. rsquoLater research suggested that it originated instead from: lsquoAnnackerrsquos, a Glasgow pork butcher from  to  their messy bins were frequently raked through by the poor.rsquo Michael Munro in his Patter, Another Blast, from  traces the origin to a firm of pork butchers, sausage makers and ham-curers: lsquoFounded in , at its height it was a chain of  branches all over the city.rsquo The company also owned a sausage factory, the last location of which was Napiershall Street .A quotation from Edinburgh in  shows that as it spread eastwards, the phrase had developed an extended meaning: lsquoTherersquos the Knackerrsquos midden at it again. Said of a person who is voracious. rsquoHowever, the original meaning of a scene of general chaos is still very much with us, as illustrated by an example from a guide to Scottish speech in the Daily Mail of September , : lsquoANNACKERrsquoS MIDDEN: A mess, a dreadful muddle. rsquoGreg Hemphill and Ford Kiernan writing in Still Game from  describe a house after a lsquoflittingrsquo as: lsquoLook at this. Itrsquos like Annickerrsquos Midden. rsquoWIDDERSHINS adverb in the wrong directionThis comes from Middle Low German weddersinnes or Middle Dutch wedersins. In the early quotations we have, it frequently refers to hair standing widdershins in response to some alarming experience lsquothat will gar all their hearts tremble and their haire start widdershinrsquo .In other contexts, there is no doubt what the wrong direction usually is. The Scotsmangives us a clue, pointing out an error made by a well-known weather presenter: lsquoHe at least should know that wind round anti-cyclones goes widdershins. rsquo Going counterclockwise or against the motion of the sun is not only wrong but inauspicious. Sir Walter Scott in the Fair Maid of Perthdescribes: lsquoA very ancient custom which consists in going three times round the body of a dead or living person, imploring blessing upon him. The Deasil must be performed sun-wayshellip If misfortune is imprecated, the party moves withershins. rsquoWe find a lot of evidence in accounts of witchcraft, such as this  quotation from A History of the Witches of Renfrewshire: lsquoUpon the pronouncing of some words, and turning himself about wider-shins, that is turning himself round from the right hand to the left, contrary to the natural course of the sun. rsquoThe New Statistical Accountrecords that Shetland fishermen, lsquowhen about to proceed to the fishing, think they would have bad luck,they were to row the boat ldquowithershins about. rsquo However, on a romantic note, the poet Allan Ransay declares : lsquoThe starns shall gang withershins ere I deceive thee. rsquoBOORACH noun a mound, an untidy heapThe SNPs Ian Blackford memorably called Brexit a clusterbourach but boorachrsquos etymology is in itself a right boorach. The Gaelic word buacuterachappears in The Dictionary of the Scots Language under the entry lsquobooragrsquo, defined as a piece of turf used as peat or for roofing, and illustrated by David Stephen in Gleanings in the Northwith this colourful quotation involving damage to daughter and dog: lsquoMaister Jolly, yin gigglegawkie, fat ye carsquo mrsquo son, dangs bowarag in my dochterrsquos ersquoe, and tramped rsquoporsquo my folpeyrsquos feetrsquo. Gaelic buacuterach comes from English burrow , from Old English beorg.The dictionary is less clear on the derivation of boorach. It may be from beorg, but it has been suggested that it may be related to Old English buror burg , which gives us burgh. Whatever the source, we find it as a mound or a heap of stones in Alexander Grayrsquos Arrows : lsquoHe has struck his fit on a bourock he trippit and slippit, and syne He fell. rsquoJames Brown in The Round Table Clubtells us: lsquotwenty deid deer waur coontit, arsquo lyinrsquo in a boorach thegither. rsquo John Black in Melodies and Memoriesdescribes seasonal cheer: lsquoOrsquo holly leaves wirsquo berries bricht, Anrsquo bouracks big orsquo cake anrsquo bun To grace the feasts anrsquo spice the fun. rsquoFrequently, boorachs are untidy, hence the use of the word to describe a teenagerrsquos bedroom or, more figuratively, avant-garde music: lsquoa new- fangled musicrsquos juist a bourockrsquo as TS Cairncross declares in the Scots Magazine .In Mairi Hedderwickrsquos Katie Morag Delivers the Mail , Grannie says: lsquoWell, this is a fine boorach yoursquove got yourself into, Katie Morag. rsquo I know it as a crowd, huddle or cluster, like ES Rae in the Banffshire Journal : lsquoAnrsquo boorichs black orsquo crawinrsquo clamrinrsquo craws. rsquoDICHT verb to wipe, clean, put in good orderNowadays, dicht is usually used in the sense of to wipe. The Aberdeen Makar, Sheena Blackhall, uses it frequently. In The Bonsai Grower , we read of mothers lsquodichtin bibbly snootsrsquo. In the DSL, it is still found in related senses such as to polish, clean or sweep. Edinburgh Burgh Recordsnote the requirement that lsquoeuery man and woman dicht and mak clene befor ther durris and closisrsquo. Stirlingrsquos defences were well cared for, because the Burgh Recordscontain an entry lsquoFor thrie sheep skins to dight the cannonrsquo.The parent Old English word dihtan had a wider range of meanings, several of which were shared by Scots and English until the word became obsolete in English in the th century.It often meant to dress or decorate. Robert Henryson in the late th century describes a magnicent lsquocroun of massie goldhellip Withhellip mony diueris dyamontis dicht. rsquo According to the lexicographer, John Jamieson : lsquoA discourse is said to be weil dicht, when the subject is well handled.rsquo Dicht could also mean to st or winnow grain and, in Angus, in the mid-th century, a strong wind could still be described as lsquoA wind at wid dicht berersquo.Food can also be dichtit, hence a hospitable proverb from David Fergussonrsquos collection : lsquoA friendrsquos dinner is soon dight.rsquo Another proverb drew upon the habit that hens have of wiping their beaks before going to roost.So, we get this political comment from James Ballantinersquos The Gaberlunziersquos Wallet : lsquoWharsquos to be prime minister say ye  Charlie Fox  Troth man, thatrsquos good news indeedhellip Troth anrsquo Billie Pitt may now ersquoen dight his neb and flee up.rsquo If you want to tell someone to take a look at themselves before criticising others, you might say lsquoDicht yer ain door stanersquo. Perhaps a lesson for our politicians ETTLE verb to intend, plan, aimThis word comes from Old Norse aeligtla and makes its first appearance in Scots around  in John Barbourrsquos Troy Book. On balance, ettlin in the DSL seems predominantly directed towards mischief but this bias could be because of splendid examples from court records. The Council Register of the Burgh of Aberdeen alone gives us: lsquoHehellip drew furth his dager, aitling to hawe strukin the said officier thairwithrsquoand, involving an unusual weapon, lsquoFor etling to strik the said Issobell with ane brasin panrsquo .The sense sometimes drts into lsquoaimrsquo as in A Rossrsquo late th century Fortunate Shepherd: lsquoA gentle squire of freely gentle cast, Of sweet address, anrsquo skillrsquod in courting art, That well coud ettle Cupidrsquos winning dartrsquo, hence J Kellyrsquos Proverbs : lsquoOft Etle, whiles hit. This he explains as ldquoPeople who have made many Tryals to do a Thing, may hit right at last.rsquoBurns uses it as a noun in Tam orsquo Shanter in which, lsquoNanniehellip flew at Tam wirsquo furious ettlersquo and this determined declaration comes from James Stewartrsquos Sketches o Scottish Character : lsquoAnrsquo I winna be put frae my ettle, Not ersquoen by auld Hornie himselrsquo.A similar determination lies behind this ambitious imperative from John Galtrsquos The Provost: lsquoYersquore ettling at the magistracyhellip and Irsquoll no let ye restye dinna makrsquo me a bailiersquos we or arsquo be done. rsquo A more modest and understandable desire is expressed in P Macgillivrayrsquos Bog-Myrtle and Peat Reek : lsquoAnrsquo aye we ettlersquot the ither dram, Wirsquo dry oatcakes for a foond.rsquoTo end on a thoughtful note, here is a sentiment from JL Waughrsquos Robbie Doo : lsquoHope! ay, itrsquos the ettler orsquo youth and the solace orsquo age: lose it, and the firstrsquos a failure and the last a burden. rsquoMINCE noun nonsense, rubbishApart from haggis, mince and tatties is one of Scotlandrsquos iconic national dishes which has nurtured many generations. Mince is so embedded in the national psyche that it has developed many unusual and inexplicable meanings. It features in insults such as: lsquoHe talks a lot o mincersquoorlsquoyer heidrsquos fu o mincersquo, yoursquore either very confused or a complete fool, as illustrated by this example from The Observer: lsquohellip tensions move the pace on to straight urban demotic, our respected Minister [David Blunkett] can expect to be told his heidrsquos full of mince, or called, most woundingly, a numpty. rsquoand, staying with politics, the Daily Record of April , , tells voters that lsquoOnly you can decide whorsquos talking mince. rsquoA stupid person or persons can be described as being as lsquothick as mincersquo, as Hardeep Singh Kohli writes: lsquoTodayrsquos Tories, for all their privilege and erudite education, are arguably the least able coterie of Conservatives we have ever had in power. Basically, they are thick as mince. rsquo Finally,someone is listless, idle or untidy, they are accused of being like a pound of mince: lsquohellip this frequenting of the Empress every afternoon and sitting about the house like a pound o mince isnae helping anybody. rsquoAnd an Edinburgh informant from  tells an untidy person: lsquoYer claes are hingin like a pun o mince. rsquoSCOOBY noun a clueRhyming slang is sometimes thought to be strictly the domain of the Cockney but it has been utilised as a device by Scots speakers too. Scooby Doo, the cartoon character created for the Hanna-Barbera Productions in , is an addition in the second edition of the Concise Scots Dictionary because, as far as we can ascertain, in the early s his name was used as the rhyming slang for lsquocluersquo.Although we cannot find any examples of his name in full, it seems always to be shortened to lsquoScoobyrsquo as in lsquoI havenrsquot got a scoobyrsquo.The earliest example that we have in our research records comes from The Herald of May , : lsquoYour lawyer telling youse that he husnae a scooby and youse can jist take a wee tirravie tae yersel.rsquo The fact that the term is used in print in a national newspaper illustrates that it was in common enough use to be understood by the general public but as with many new Scots words finding evidence in print is very dficult.Many of the current examples seem to be concerned with our national obsession with football as this example from Grant Stott writing in the Edinburgh Evening News of January , : lsquoIf I had a pound for every time someone has asked me or texted me the question, ldquoBig man, whatrsquos happening with yer team  Irsquod have hellip well, a few quid now. And the answer is always the same. I havenrsquot got a Scooby. rsquo There is as ever, as with much of research, a hunt on for earlier examples of this phrase.SPEEL verb to climb, clamberThe derivation of this word is obscure the earliest recorded meaning in the Dictionary of the Scots Language is: lsquoto perform as an acrobatrsquo and dates from . Later, it widens its meaning to include lsquoTo mount, ascend to a height by climbing to climb, clamberhelliprsquo The OED suggests that it may originally derive from lsquoolder Flemish or Low German spelerplayer, actor. rsquoAt Christmas and other times when party invitations are forthcoming, speel comes to mind as a candidate for The Heralds Word of the Week because of a reply in verse given by Robert Burns, writing in , to just such an invitation: lsquoSir, Yours this moment I unseal, And faith Irsquom gay and hearty! To tell the truth and shame the deil, I am as fou as Bartie: But Foorsday, sir, my promise leal, Expect me olsquo your partie, If on a beastie I can speel, Or hurl in a cartie. Yours, Robert Burns. Mauchline, Monday night,  orsquoclock.rsquoThe verse creates a clear mental picture of a slightly tipsy Burns trying to clamber onto his horse. Most other examples in the DSL are centred round scaling less mobile objects than horses. In , O Douglas in Farewell to Priorsford wrote: lsquoNaebody had ever tried to spiel thae rocks. rsquo Figurative uses are well documented too. The following is from RW Thomrsquos Jock o Knowe: lsquoTam Gripper, then nae laird atweel, Maun up the social ladder speel.rsquo SCUNNERED: How many of us will be feeling by the time this General Election campaign is over. Favourite Scots Words, edited by Pauline Cairns Speitel, is published by Luath at pound.

title: herald-diary-quirky-questions
story: BORIS Johnson has spent the week ducking, ing and dodging questions that political broadcasters were eager to ask him. The Diary, of course, never avoids the important debates of the day. We are happy to field even the daftest of inquiries, though admittedly we canrsquot always provide an answer, sensible or otherwise. We look back now on some of those puzzlers posed to us in the past. For instance, a reader once enquiredman evolved from apes, why do we still have apes Pulling a crackerA SEASONAL head-scratcherhellip Question: Why is Santa so jolly  Answer: Because he knows where all the bad girls live.Pure steamingA QUESTION of interest to women hoping to raise a family. Does the potential father of your baby have to be smart  An apocryphal tale we were once told may provide an answer. A chap was required to take a sperm sample to a fertility clinic in Glasgow. He was advised by telephone that he should put the test tube in a warm pocket. The patient decided to take no chances. He arrived and handed the receptionist a foil-wrapped package. When opened the contents emitted a quantity of steam. The staff were certainly surprised, as they had never before seen a test-tube sample nestling in a baked potato.West is bestREADERS often enquirea certain area of Glasgow is as chic as legend would have it. For an answer we recall this scene set in a West End garden, where a spot of afternoon tea was being taken outdoors, the weather being awfy clammy. The man of the house was stung by a wasp but was taking it all quite calmly. He called through the open windae to his dear we to pass him some vinegar to treat the sting. ldquoDo you want ordinary or balsamic  his West End lady replied.Pilfered petalsA QUERY regarding our educational system. Are our school children out of control, or just misunderstood wee scamps with a twinkle in their eye  A Port Glasgow teacher provided us with an answer. She reported that she was once supervising the line of pupils, first thing in the morning. A ten-year-old boy pushed half a dozen bedraggled daffodils into her hands with the words: ldquoHere, miss, these are fur you. Ah would huv goat mair but the wumman banged on the windae.Menu mix-upREADERS often want to knowpubs are becoming far too swanky. Perhaps. Though wersquore not so sure about the clientele. We once heard a tale about a wee wumman of advanced years who entered a pub in Cathcart and asked a member of staff: ldquoWhitrsquos your special  The chap glanced at the blackboard and began to recite: ldquoOur special today is breaded lobster tails on a selection of salad leaves with a marie-rose dip. Itrsquos served with carrots julienne and baby sweetcorn and a choice of potatoes, croquettes, hash browns, or French fries. At that, the woman put on a pained expression and said to him: ldquoNaw, your special. title: alan-roden-tv-confrontations-exposed-lack-honest-answers-politicians
story: A stony silence.ldquoYou said your party has a zero-tolerance approach to Islamophobia, so what action should be taken against you for using the term lsquoletterboxrsquo to describe Muslim women who wear a burqa More silence.ldquoWill you tell voters the truth about your relationship with businesswoman Jenner Arcuri and why you didnrsquot declare a personal interest when you were London Mayor Yet more silence.If Boris Johnson really does fail to appear for a grilling by Andrew Neil, the BBC should just go ahead with a half-hour prime-time programme where the Prime Minister is empty chaired.Mr Neil could read out the questions he would have asked anyway, making for compelling viewing. But perhaps even that would be a risk that Dominic Cummings and Tory advisers would be willing to take. After all, those who have agreed to an Andrew Neil interview in this election campaign have found it an unforgiving experience.First up was Nicola Sturgeon.The First Minister is an accomplished media performer ndash easily the most competent politician in front of a camera in Scotland, and surely in the top ten across the UK.Her interview wasnrsquot quite the car crash that social media would perhaps suggest, but it was certainly a deeply uncomfortable  minutes.Her wild assertions about how easily an independent Scotland could stroll into the EU were ruthlessly exposed, and she may come to regret describing the SNPrsquos currency tribulations as a lsquojourneyrsquo.The -second-long list of problems facing the NHS under the Nationalists also deserved the million-plus audience it has since received online. Yet at times the First Minister held her own and, realistically, her performance is unlikely to cost the SNP many votes.However, it might help some Labour left-wingers in England understand why their Scottish colleagues get so angry when they describe Ms Sturgeon as a comrade.Predictably, the Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, fared far worse in his own interview. Thoroughly displeased at being there, he repeatedly struggled to explain how he would pay for his manesto promises.Then, with voters screaming lsquojust apologisersquo at their TV sets, he refused four times to say sorry for the anti-semitism shaming his leadership.If heads were in their hands at Labour HQ, the verdict in Tory HQ will have been lsquowellhellip sod thatrsquo.The Andrew Neil interviews have given voters some food for thought, as these set-piece TV events should.The ITV head-to-head between Mr Johnson and Mr Corbyn has been the only major let-down so far, with a bizarre format which gave neither politician enough time to answer the questions. On this occasion, the victors were those not invited ndash Jo Swinson and Nicola Sturgeon. With hindsight, perhaps they should have saved their parties from the huge legal bill of trying to get on the line-up.In contrast, the winners in Thursday nightrsquos climate change debate were those who did appear, with Boris Johnson and Nigel Farage reduced to ice sculptures for not showing up.When it comes to how much impact these debates have on the final election result, the jury is out ndash Cleggmania in  didnrsquot really translate to Commons seats.But Electoral Reform Society research has found that  per cent of people believe debates are important, and a third say theyre key to helping them decide how to vote.They want to see points put across clearly, factual evidence for claims, and a debate that engages the audience watching at home. And as well as being watched by millions, they certainly set the campaign narrative.In , Alistair Darling bested Alex Salmond in the first TV debate of the independence campaign. If you canrsquot remember it, Mr Salmond decided to ask questions about alien attacks, while Mr Darling pointed out that an eight-year-old could name their countryrsquos capital, flag and currency, but Mr Salmond couldnrsquot say what currency an independent Scotland would use.In the  election campaign, I was involved behind-the-scenes in the Scottish TV debates. The amount of preparation work was immense. Days of going over attack lines, defence lines, introductory remarks, key messages, second-guessing opponents, and the occasional bit of role-play.Spin doctors had their own role to play on the night as well. The first debate on the BBC involved a nurse telling Ms Sturgeon to her face that NHS staff were having to use foodbanks. While journalists in the spin room tried to file their copy, political advisers interrupted them, talking up their own employer to some extent, but mainly talking down the rest of the line-up.For the SNP, this backfired when the message was spread that the nursersquos husband was a Tory councillor. It categorically wasnrsquot true.However, the Nationalists had a better night of it at the STV debate. Unusually, the broadcaster decided not to provide inidual green rooms for the politicians, so they all had to share the same space for a long time before taking to the stage.Willie Rennie and Ruth Davidson dealt with this through humour, cracking jokes to demonstrate confidence. Kez Dugdale, who I was working for, focused on her notes. Nicola Sturgeon kept herself to herself. She had something up her sleeve.In the debate, she claimed that Kez once told her in a private conversation in the aftermath of Brexit that Labour might rethink its opposition to an independence referendum ndash something she strongly denied. But having run a campaign focused on opposition to independence, this was a lsquogotcharsquo moment. It was, comfortably, the toughest moment of the campaign.So I wish my successors at Scottish Labour, and at all parties, every good fortune for the coming days.This campaign still has nearly a fortnight to run. The Scottish TV debates have yet to be broadcast, there is another Prime Ministerial head-to-head to come, and it remains to be seenBoris Johnson will sit down with Andrew Neil.There are a lot of nervous politicians, and a lot of nervous spin doctors. They have a right to be nervous, because the voters deserve more honest answers.

title: aberdeenshire council wishes you a very mer recycling christmas
story: Aberdeenshire Council is wishing North-east residents a very mer-recycling Christmas as the festive season fast approaches.This year the local authority is encouraging householders to ensure landfill is not on their Christmas wish list as arrangements for festive recycling and waste collections are unveiled.Households create more waste at this time of year as a result of buying excess food and presents, wrapping paper, cards and possibly even their Christmas tree. But residents can help save tax-payers’ money by making better use of available recycling services and avoiding sending items to landfill unnecessarily, as sending waste to landfill costs much more than recycling.Waste team manager Andrew Sheridan explains: “In terms of food waste, first and foremost we are encouraging residents to reuse their leftover turkey and vegetables in warming casseroles, tasty pies or even bespoke pizzas.“Failing that then you can recycle foodstuffs in your food caddies which are collected from homes every week.”And when it comes to the array of Christmas-related materials we accumulate, there are many types of cardboard, non-glittery Christmas cards and other items which can all be popped into your blue-lidded kerbside bins which are picked up fortnightly.Andrew explains: “Wrapping paper can only be recycledit passes the scrunch test - simple paper wrap can be recycled, but foil or glitter-decorated paper cannot and needs to go in the general waste. It’s astonishing just how much of this material can actually be turned into new products,instead of rotting away for years in landfill.“To help ensure householders make the most of their Christmas materials, a host of fun festive recycling tips will be published on the council’s social media channels, including ideas for presents that won’t cost the earth.”When it comes to real Christmas trees and larger items of cardboard packaging, these can be taken to Aberdeenshire’s recycling centres. But you should note that the council’s network of recycling centres will be closed from pm on Tuesday, December  until am on Friday, December  and from pm Tuesday, December  until am on Friday, January . title: co op shares festive funding boost with six local causes
story: Six local groups have received an early Christmas present in the form of Co-op funding.This is the latest round of pay outs from the local community fund, and brings the amount the Co-op members have invested in local causes since the scheme launched in September  to £,.The successful groups were The Victoria Hall Trust , Daviot Community Trust , Girlguiding Ellon District , nd Oldmeldrum Brownies , Auchnagatt Village Halland Kayleigh’s Wee Stars .Rebecca Birkbeck, Director of Community and Shared Value at the Co-op, commented: “The local community fund is now a well-established way of supporting local causes who help to make communities safer, happier, and healthier places to live, and we’re delighted to be able to support such a wide range of local groups in Aberdeenshire.“By choosing their local cause online, our members are telling us what really matters in their communities, and we have used this information to help us identy new groups to support throughout next year.“Feedback from our own Community Wellbeing Index – which highlights the areas where communities can benefit from support – has shown us that we should be focused on protecting and improving community spaces, helping people reach their full potential by developing their skills, and promoting health and wellbeing.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: inverurie club marks decade of success
story: Inverurie Loco Works Football Club has once again celebrated the very best of business that the North East has to offer with its th annual Business Lunch, sponsored by CALA Homes.Held at The Marclfe Hotel in Aberdeen on Friday, November , the event is one of the most popular events on the North East business calendar.It celebrated it’s tenth consecutive year with theof guest speaker Lady Michelle Mone OBE, following her appearance at the very first Loco Works Business Lunch a decade ago.Lady Mone shared stories of her rise from humble Glasgow-raised bra-designer to a global entrepreneur, and tales of her international business journey.Leading homebuilder CALA Homes was on board once again as the headline sponsor of the  event, as part of its long standing support of the Scottish Highland Football Leagueclub.Mike Naysmith, Managing Director at CALA Homes, commented: “We were thrilled to be able to support the Loco Works Business Lunch as it celebrated  years of bringing Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire’s brightest business minds together.“We’ve supported the club for a number of years and it’s a pleasure to continue our close links with the team and the town of Inverurie.”Vice Chairman and event organiser at the club, Graeme Hay, added: “We pulled out of all the stops to mark ten years of our business lunch and we’re delighted to see it was a huge success.“I’d like to thank Lady Mone for ing to mark the occasion with some truly inspiring stories, CALA Homes for supporting the event and everyone who attended to make the day memorable.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: kintore firm marks 20th anniversary
story: A north-east firm has held a family fun day to celebrate  years in business.eBlast, part of the eGroup, welcomed around  people of all ages to its Kintore headquarters at the Midmill Industrial Estate to help mark the anniversary.Since first opening its doors at the former Inverurie loco works in  with only four employees and a forklt truck, the business has evolved to become one of the largest specialist coatings and surface preparation businesses in the UK and an expert in specialist coatings for extreme environments.Over the past two decades, eBlast has largely focused on meeting the needs of customers in the energy sector with clients ranging from local fabricators to major suppliers to the oil and gas, renewables and construction industries.Speaking at the event Neil McDonald, CEO and chairman of eGroup, proudly commented: “Our people are what has made the company successful and I would like to thank them all for their level of service, reliability and commitment to our clients, which is second-to-none.“It’s their passion which has undoubtedly driven the business forward to this landmark th anniversary.”In , eBlast and its sister companies amalgamated to form the eGroup and provide an integrated service that combines commercial and industrial coating, painting and surface preparation with structural steel fabrication, cladding installation and non-destructive testingservices, among other specialisms.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Eilish enjoys lunch with pupils from Oyne Primary School"  Olympian inspires Oyne pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: olympian inspires oyne pupils
story: Pupils at Oyne Primary had a special visitor last month as Scottish Olympian and Commonwealth athlete Eilish McColgan spent a morning with pupils, staff and parents.The visit on Friday, November  was organised by Active Schools Aberdeenshire and supported by local business Logie Country House, and arranged through the “Champions In Scotland” programme.The Dundee-born runner spoke to pupils from P to P about her career so far and focused on how pupils could achieve their “personal best”.She led a short session of dynamic warms ups and one of the highlights of the morning was a question and answer session, which included some parents with children at the school.Questions ranged from her favourite event so far, which was the  Olympics in London, her motivation to keep running faster and an overview of her training, diet and sleep routine, all aimed at achieving her “personal best” whenever she competes for Scotland or Great Britain.Pupils also got to see some of her medal collection, with last year’s European Championship Silver in the m in Berlin being a standout, and the experience for the pupils was made even better when Eilish joined them for school lunch.Eilish also met Stef and Tim Erbe, who as the owners of Logie Country House have supported the extra-curricular programme at Oyne Primary School this school year, which includes a jogging club.Before heading home to begin her preparations for the Olympics in Japan next summer, Eilish also had time to visit Inverurie Academy, where she met a class of S pupils. They also took the chance to have a question and answer session and have an Olympic athlete give them some coaching tips. Active Schools Lead Coordinator for Central Aberdeenshire, Malcolm Grant, said: “Across Scotland this month the sporting theme from sportscotland is Local Heroes and Eilish ticked every box during her visits to Oyne Primary and Inverurie Academy. “The focus on personal best resonates strongly across a broad range of school subjects, not just sport, but having Eilish presenting her thoughts on her own career and how she intends to continue to improve and progress, despite her already extensive achievements in athletics, ensured that all of the pupils went home with some extra inspiration and motivation to do the best that they can, whatever they choose to do in the future.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Neil McDonald, Scott Duguid and Peter Taylor at the eBlast celebration event"  Kintore firm marks th anniversaryviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Lady Michelle Mone OBE attended the Inverurie Loco Works Football Club Business Lunch"  Inverurie club marks decade of success viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: gearing up for the orkney nature festival
story: Spring may seem a long way off, but that hasn#t deterred RSPB Scotland from announcing the dates of their Spring time nature festival.The eighth Orkney Nature Festival will take place from May  to , , and will be embracing a marine theme it was announced last week.  The festival, popular with Orkney locals and visitors alike, is an annual celebration of the unique wildle and natural heritage of the county with events across the Mainland and islands. The programme is made up of a iety of nature-themed events run by local organisations and iniduals and co-ordinated each year by the local RSPB Scotland team.“The Nature Festival is a fantastic opportunity for people to learn more about the special wildle of Orkney, take part in activities, and maybe even discover an island they’ve not visited before,# said RSPB Scotland’s events and communications officer for Orkney, Eleanor Davison.# being the Visit Scotland Year of Coasts and Waters certainly works well for Orkney and we look forward to providing even more coastal-themed events and activities than usual!”The festival is a chance for the people of Orkney to showcase and celebrate the natural wonders that Orkney has to offer and for local businesses to raise awareness of what they do, and so RSPB Scotland are keen for folk to get involved.“We know many people plan trips to Orkney each year to coincide with the festival week, and we aim to provide a range of events, activities and new experiences for all,# added Eleanor.#We are keen to highlight Orkney’s spectacular wildle and get people interacting with nature. With growing awareness of the huge threats facing wildle and habitats in the UK and across the world, it would be great to have more festival events which focus on the importance of looking after our environment and give people the opportunity to get involved on a local level to help save nature.#I would like to encourage anyone who has an idea for an event they would like to run to get in touch as soon as possible.”Any organisation or inidual who would like to take part in the  festival can contact Eleanor at the RSPB Orkney office in Stromness on  or email orkney@rspb.org.uk  For more information on the festival as it becomes available you can check out the website at: www.orkneynaturefestival.orgOr visit the festival#s Facebook page at: www.facebook OrkneyNatureFestivalcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: kirkwall boasts scotlands most beautiful high street
story: Kirkwall has been named Scotland’s Most Beautul High Street having topped a poll of the general public.The chair of the Kirkwall Business Improvement District, Duncan McLean, who made the submission on behalf of the town, said: “We at Kirkwall BID are delighted that our town has won this very special award.#It recognises both the beauty of the town’s historic centre, and the efforts of local iniduals, public bodies and voluntary organisations to make the town a wonderful place to live, work and socialise.“Most importantly, it was the support of our community that won this award, and to know that the people of Kirkwall love and are proud of their town is the best reward of all.”Having received  per cent of nearly , votes, Kirkwall faced off stf competition from Lerwick, who secured  per cent of the vote. East Dunbartonshire town, Milgavnie, came in a close third on  per cent.The national competition for Scotland’s Most Beautul High Street is run by two of Scotland’s most well known organisations for place and the environment — Scotland’s Towns Partnership, the national body for towns in Scotland, and Keep Scotland Beautul, the environmental charity which campaigns to keep Scotland green, clean and sustainable. The online vote took place over a four-week period.Phil Prentice, chief officer of Scotland’s Towns Partnership, said: “This competition is all about recognising the work and effort of local people to make their high streets the best they can be. It’s not just an award for a high street, it’s an award for the people who occupy it.#I’ve seen first hand just some of the innovation and forward thinking used in Kirkwall and it is a real demonstration of what can be achieved with creativity and determination.“I want to warmly congratulate Kirkwall, and all of the worthy towns who were shortlisted. It’s no secret that our high streets have been under pressure for the past few years, but this competition gives us hope for the future.#When people come together and take ownership of their places, great things can happen and big challenges can be overcome.”Katie Murray, communities and place manager at Keep Scotland Beautul, commented: #I would like to offer my congratulations to Kirkwall for being selected as Scotland#s most beautul high street.#This is a fantastic example of how, by working in partnership, signicant improvements can be brought forward to improve the town centre experience for residents and visitors alike. #Every participant in the competition deserves recognition for the benefits that they are delivering across Scotland — helping everyone to enjoy cleaner, greener and more beautul communities.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: sale of orkney goose meat extented
story: newsSale of Orkney goose meat extendedNovember ,  at : pm vw, px"  The sale of greylag goose meat on Orkney has been extended to January  next year.Scottish Natural Heritagehave said they hope this will encourage the use of fresh, seasonal, wild goose meat and help boost local business.The sustainable control of resident greylag geese populations is licensed to safeguard agricultural crops, as part of the Orkney Resident Greylag Goose Project. The project was allowed to sell meat until October , and this extension takes advantage of the European Commission’s approval for Scotland-wide sales until any new potential EU exit date.These licences permit the sale of resident greylag goose meat in Scotland directly to consumers as well as to retailers, such as hotels and butchers.Claudia Rowse, SNH’s head of natural resource management said #We are delighted to announce the continued sale of resident greylag goose meat. Now, licensed sellers from Orkney will have a chance to develop the market for their product and people can try goose for themselves, on Orkney, and across Scotland.“Wild geese are an important part of Scotland’s nature, but their rapid rise in numbers has been challenging for farmers and crofters. We know that striking the balance between conservation, farming and hunting can be dficult.“Our goal is to give farmers and crofters the tools they need to safeguard their crops, allowing them to control goose numbers sustainably and sell goose meat for profit.”SNH have said they are working to secure longer-term arrangements for the sale of resident greylag goose meat in Scotland. A project review will take place in January , in light of the UK’s EU exit arrangements, and take into account any changes arising from the current review of its General Licences.Sale of wild goose meat shot outside the project is prohibited under the Wildle and Countryside Act .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: uk ambassadors from norway sweden and iceland visit orkney
story: The ambassadors to the UK for Norway, Sweden and Iceland are visiting Orkney over the next few days, touring the county, meeting with the local council and attending the Kirkwall Christmas tree-lighting.The ambassador for Norway Wegger Strømmen has been joined on a trip to the county by Stefan Haukur Johannessonand Torbjörn Sohlström .Today saw them sit down to lunch with leaders from Orkney Islands Council, before visiting the UNESCO World Heritage Sites.Tomorrow will see the three ambassadors head to Kirkwall#s Broad Street for the town#s annual Christmas Tree-lighting. The trees that will stand inside and outside the St Magnus Cathedral are from Grimstad and Hordaland, in Norway, respectively.Speaking during an event at the Robert Rendall building in Stromness today Mr Strømmen talked about the visit to Orkney so far — which is a first for him.He said: #There are two things that really stand out when it comes to Orkney — there is the Viking tradition and the fact that Orkney was part of Norway many hundreds of years ago. That legacy, in a way, is still here.#For us, coming to Orkney is a bit like coming home and I hope people will take that in a good sense. In the way society works here, there is something we recognise instantly. I think this is the same for the Icelanders and Swedish.#The Kirkwall Christmas Tree lighting will take place outside St Magnus Cathedral from .pm tomorrow, Saturday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
